The San Francisco Ferry Building is a mecca of food, wine, coffee chocolate, restaurants and more centered in the heart of the most beautiful city on the planet (to me at least). This light open space is bustling with locals during the day, looking for a delicious bite, and a shot of hot locally roasted coffee, or a sip of wine! From famed chefs like Charles Phan (The Slanted Door) and Amaryll Schwertner (Boulette's Larder) to the perfect places to grab a bottle to go (Ferry Plaza Wine Merchants) this is a must-stop for anybody visiting SF. Make your plans! CUESA's farmer's markets are every Saturday (massive) with Tuesday and Thursday markets as well. The Building is open with the wonderful vendors every day, but for the extra special local's treatment, I would suggest visiting on a market day. On the market days, there are visiting chefs (Jacques Pepin has been known to stop by), plus restaurant pop-ups and more.

This marketplace runs the entire length of the 1898 Ferry Building's ground floor and includes short side corridors. We first walked its entire length one Sunday morning, looking for a place to have breakfast before taking a ferry to Sausalito. We found it convenient to have this food hall so close to our hotel, because many breakfast places in the vicinity had yet to open or are closed on Sundays.

The main corridor offered mostly baked goods and coffee at 9:30 a.m. and the small number of visitors seemed to cluster at these shops. It wasn't until we turned onto a short corridor that we saw Frog Hollow Farms, where I was able to buy oatmeal, fruit and coffee. This eatery proved to be just steps away from where the Sausalito ferry departs.

On our return in late afternoon, crowds shuffled in both directions along the long corridor with visitors stopping at various stalls to look at the merchandise. That included honey, olive oil, pottery, cheese and books. Ice cream shops featured long lines and dozens of diners sat at an eatery focused on oysters. Vegetable displays enticed visitors into a small supermarket. Since morning, this had become a popular place.

Outside, we turned to take one last look at the Ferry building itself. I like its Beaux Arts style and arched arcades. But the 245-foot clock tower remains its most distinctive feature. The tower displays four clock faces, each 22 feet in diameter.

So, I chose to check out the ferry building after the exploritorum, which is right next door. At first I just wanted to see what shoo were in there, and maybe grab a bite to eat before heading back to merit lake. There were many shops and eateries in this building, and since I had frozen trader Joes food back at my hotel freezer, I really didn't want to purchase an entrée. I decided to stop at El Portend Empanadas, for a empanada. The empanada was cold, and it would've been nice if the server offered to warm it up...but she didnt. She was more interested in her conversation with another employee. So, I ate my cold empanada, and once finished, I had a craving for a glass of wine. Luckily, Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant was 10 paces away. They are a wine bar and a wine retailer with fairly knowledgeable staff. I really love champagne, but wasn't willing to pay a premium for a dry bubbly, offered on this menu, so I ordered a rose, a chardonnay, and a sparkling wine. Not all together, but as I finished each glass. They were all good, I am writing this review more than 4 weeks after returning jome, so excuse my inability to remember the names of the wines. My day had come to an end, and within 5 minutes I had an uber waiting for me outside the ferry building to wisk me back to my hotel. So, my take is, check it out, but know that you will be paying a premium for everything.
